definition:
Let $X,Y$ be topological spaces, $A$ a closed subspace of $X$ and
$f,g:X \to Y$ continuous maps. A *homotopy of maps* is a continuous
function $F:X \times [0,1] \to Y$ satisfying

1.  $F(x,0)=f(x)$ for all $x \in X$

2.  $F(x,1)=g(x)$ for all $x \in X$

3.  $F(x,t)=f(x)=g(x)$ for all $x \in A, t\in [0,1]$.

We say that $f$ is homotopic to $g$ relative to $A$ and denote this by
$f \simeq g$ $rel A$. If $A=\emptyset$, this can be written
$f \simeq g$. If $g$ is the constant map (i.e. $g(x)=y$ for all
$x \in X$), then we say that $f$ is *nullhomotopic*.
